    Character Systems

    Character Creation

    Let's start with a basic Character class that will be the foundation for our system:

    #include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
#include <map>

class Character {
public:
    Character(std::string name, int level = 1) : name(name), level(level) {}

    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    int getLevel() const { return level; }

private:
    std::string name;
    int level;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero");
    std::cout << "Created character: " << hero.getName() << " (Level " << hero.getLevel() << ")" << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

    Character Customization

    Character customization in games is a feature that allows players to create and personalize their in-game characters according to their preferences. This feature enhances the overall gaming experience by providing players with a sense of ownership and uniqueness. Here are some ways character customization can be implemented effectively:

    1. Appearance: This includes options for hair style, color, and length, facial features, skin tone, body type, and clothing. Players should be able to choose from a variety of options to create a character that looks unique and appealing.

    2. Equipment: Allow players to customize their character's equipment, such as weapons, armor, and accessories. This not only affects the character's appearance but also their abilities and skills in the game.

    3. Backstory: Provide options for players to create a backstory for their character. This could include their name, age, gender, race, occupation, and personal goals. This adds depth to the character and makes them more relatable to the player.

    4. Skills and Abilities: Allow players to allocate skill points to various attributes such as strength, intelligence, dexterity, and charisma. This can significantly impact how the character interacts with the game world and the challenges they face.

    5. Voice and Dialogue: In games with voice-over, allow players to choose the voice actor for their character. This can make the character more engaging and personal to the player. Additionally, some games may allow players to customize their character's dialogue options.

    6. Personality Traits: Offer a selection of personality traits that players can assign to their character. This can influence the character's interactions with NPCs and other players, adding another layer of depth to the game.

    7. Color Schemes: Allow players to customize the color scheme of their character or their equipment. This can make the character stand out in the game world and express the player's personal style.

    8. Tattoos and Scars: Offer options for players to add tattoos, scars, or other marks to their character. This can add to the character's backstory and make them more unique.

    9. Accessories: Allow players to add accessories to their character, such as hats, glasses, or jewelry. This can further enhance the character's appearance and make them more distinctive.

    10. Customization Levels: Offer different levels of customization, such as a basic customization option for free and a premium customization option for a fee. This allows players to customize their character to their desired level without limiting the free-to-play experience.

    Effective character customization can significantly enhance the gaming experience by making players feel more connected to their characters and the game world. It can also increase player engagement and satisfaction, as players are more likely to invest time and effort into a character they have personally created and customized.

    Let's add customization options to our Character class:

    class Character {
public:
    Character(std::string name, int level = 1) : name(name), level(level) {}

    void setAppearance(std::string hairColor, std::string eyeColor, std::string skinTone) {
        appearance["Hair Color"] = hairColor;
        appearance["Eye Color"] = eyeColor;
        appearance["Skin Tone"] = skinTone;
    }

    void displayAppearance() const {
        std::cout << "Appearance:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [feature, value] : appearance) {
            std::cout << feature << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    std::string name;
    int level;
    std::map<std::string, std::string> appearance;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero");
    hero.setAppearance("Brown", "Blue", "Fair");
    hero.displayAppearance();
    return 0;
}

    Skill Trees and Progression

    Let's implement a basic skill system:

    class Skill {
public:
    Skill(std::string name, int level = 0) : name(name), level(level) {}

    void levelUp() { ++level; }
    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    int getLevel() const { return level; }

private:
    std::string name;
    int level;
};

class Character {
public:
    // ... previous code ...

    void learnSkill(const Skill& skill) {
        skills.push_back(skill);
    }

    void improveSkill(const std::string& skillName) {
        for (auto& skill : skills) {
            if (skill.getName() == skillName) {
                skill.levelUp();
                std::cout << name << " improved " << skillName << " to level " << skill.getLevel() << std::endl;
                return;
            }
        }
        std::cout << "Skill not found!" << std::endl;
    }

    void displaySkills() const {
        std::cout << "Skills:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& skill : skills) {
            std::cout << "- " << skill.getName() << " (Level " << skill.getLevel() << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    // ... previous code ...
    std::vector<Skill> skills;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero");
    hero.learnSkill(Skill("Fireball"));
    hero.learnSkill(Skill("Healing"));
    hero.improveSkill("Fireball");
    hero.displaySkills();
    return 0;
}

    Leveling Systems

    Leveling systems in games are mechanisms that allow players to progress through the game by gaining experience points (XP) and increasing their character's level. This system provides a sense of achievement and progression, and it can significantly enhance the overall gaming experience. Here are some ways to create an effective leveling system:

    1. Experience Points (XP): XP should be awarded to players for completing various in-game tasks, such as defeating enemies, completing quests, or exploring new areas. The amount of XP awarded should be balanced to ensure that players can level up at a reasonable pace without feeling overwhelmed.

    2. Level Progression: The level progression curve should be designed to provide a steady increase in difficulty as the player levels up. This can be achieved by increasing the level of enemies, increasing the complexity of quests, or introducing new game mechanics.

    3. Skill Points: Award players with skill points as they level up, which they can use to enhance their character's abilities and skills. This allows players to customize their character's strengths and weaknesses, and it adds a layer of depth to the game.

    4. Perks and Rewards: Offer players perks and rewards for reaching certain levels, such as new equipment, abilities, or cosmetic items. This can provide additional incentive for players to level up and progress through the game.

    5. Level Caps: Implement a level cap to prevent players from becoming overpowered. This can help maintain balance in the game and ensure that the endgame remains challenging.

    6. Experience Sharing: Implement a system that allows players to share experience points with other players in their party. This can make leveling up more efficient and enjoyable for players who are playing together.

    7. Grinding Mechanics: Offer players alternative ways to gain experience points, such as completing daily or weekly challenges, participating in events, or completing side quests. This can help players level up more quickly without feeling like they are grinding the same tasks over and over.

    8. Level Scaling: Implement a system that scales the difficulty of enemies and quests based on the player's level. This can help ensure that players are always challenged, regardless of their level.

    9. Level Gating: Implement level gating to prevent players from accessing areas or content that is too difficult for them. This can help maintain balance in the game and ensure that players are always challenged, but not overwhelmed.

    10. Progression Visualization: Provide players with clear visual indicators of their progress, such as a level bar, a skill tree, or a map that shows the areas they have explored. This can help players understand their progress and plan their next steps.

    An effective leveling system can significantly enhance the gaming experience by providing players with a sense of achievement, progression, and customization. It can also increase player engagement and satisfaction, as players are more likely to invest time and effort into the game if they feel like they are making meaningful progress.

    Let's add a leveling system to our Character class:

    class Character {
public:
    // ... previous code ...

    void gainExperience(int exp) {
        experience += exp;
        std::cout << name << " gained " << exp << " experience points." << std::endl;
        checkLevelUp();
    }

    void checkLevelUp() {
        int expRequired = level * 100; // Simple formula: level * 100 exp to level up
        if (experience >= expRequired) {
            level++;
            experience -= expRequired;
            std::cout << name << " leveled up to level " << level << "!" << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    // ... previous code ...
    int experience = 0;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero");
    hero.gainExperience(150);
    std::cout << "Current level: " << hero.getLevel() << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

    Class Systems

    Let's implement a basic class system:

    enum class CharacterClass { Warrior, Mage, Rogue };

class Character {
public:
    Character(std::string name, CharacterClass charClass) 
        : name(name), characterClass(charClass) {}

    void displayClass() const {
        std::cout << "Class: ";
        switch (characterClass) {
            case CharacterClass::Warrior: std::cout << "Warrior"; break;
            case CharacterClass::Mage: std::cout << "Mage"; break;
            case CharacterClass::Rogue: std::cout << "Rogue"; break;
        }
        std::cout << std::endl;
    }

private:
    // ... previous code ...
    CharacterClass characterClass;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character warrior("Warrior", CharacterClass::Warrior);
    warrior.displayClass();
    return 0;
}

    Class systems are a fundamental aspect of many games, particularly in role-playing games (RPGs) and massively multiplayer online games (MMOs). They provide structure, diversity, and specialization to characters within a game. Let's dive deeper into class systems in games:

    1. Purpose of Class Systems:

      • Differentiation: Classes give players distinct roles and playstyles.
      • Specialization: Each class excels in certain areas while having weaknesses in others.
      • Teamwork: In multiplayer games, different classes can complement each other.
      • Replayability: Players can experience the game differently with each class.

    2. Common Types of Classes:

      • Warrior/Fighter: Melee combat specialists, often with high defense.
      • Mage/Wizard: Spellcasters who use magic for offense and utility.
      • Rogue/Thief: Stealthy characters focused on agility and precision.
      • Healer/Cleric: Support characters who can heal and buff allies.
      • Ranger/Archer: Ranged combat specialists.
      • Tank: Defensive characters who absorb damage for the team.
      • Support/Buffer: Characters who enhance allies' abilities.

    3. Class Attributes:

      • Each class typically has strengths in certain attributes (e.g., Warriors in Strength, Mages in Intelligence).
      • Classes often have unique resource systems (e.g., Mana for Mages, Rage for Warriors).

    4. Skill Sets:

      • Classes usually have unique skill trees or ability sets.
      • Some skills might be shared between classes, while others are class-exclusive.

    5. Equipment and Gear:

      • Classes often have restrictions on what types of equipment they can use.
      • Some games feature class-specific legendary items or sets.

    6. Class Balance:

      • Developers strive to make all classes viable and appealing.
      • Balance is crucial in competitive games to ensure fairness.

    7. Class Progression:

      • As characters level up, they often gain new abilities specific to their class.
      • Some games allow multi-classing or subclass specializations.

    8. Class Roles in Team Play:

      • In group content, classes often fill specific roles (DPS, Tank, Healer, Support).
      • Class synergies can be crucial for team strategies.

    9. Class Customization:

      • Many modern games allow for customization within a class (talent trees, skill choices).
      • This allows players to tailor their playstyle while maintaining class identity.

    10. Hybrid Classes:

      • Some games feature hybrid classes that combine aspects of two or more traditional classes.
      • Examples: Paladin (Warrior + Healer), Battlemage (Warrior + Mage)

    11. Class Evolution in Games:

      • Early RPGs had rigid class systems with little customization.
      • Modern games often offer more flexibility and hybrid options.
      • Some games are moving towards classless systems with full customization.

    12. Narrative Integration:

      • Classes can be tied to the game's lore and world-building.
      • Class choice might affect dialogue options or story progression in some games.

    Let's expand our previous C++ implementation to showcase a more detailed class system:

    #include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
#include <map>

enum class ClassType { Warrior, Mage, Rogue, Cleric };

class Ability {
public:
    Ability(std::string name, int power, int manaCost) 
        : name(name), power(power), manaCost(manaCost) {}

    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    int getPower() const { return power; }
    int getManaCost() const { return manaCost; }

private:
    std::string name;
    int power;
    int manaCost;
};

class CharacterClass {
public:
    CharacterClass(ClassType type, std::string name, std::map<std::string, int> baseStats)
        : type(type), name(name), baseStats(baseStats) {}

    void addAbility(const Ability& ability) {
        abilities.push_back(ability);
    }

    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    ClassType getType() const { return type; }
    std::map<std::string, int> getBaseStats() const { return baseStats; }

    void displayInfo() const {
        std::cout << "Class: " << name << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Base Stats:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [stat, value] : baseStats) {
            std::cout << "  " << stat << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
        std::cout << "Abilities:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& ability : abilities) {
            std::cout << "  " << ability.getName() << " (Power: " << ability.getPower() 
                      << ", Mana Cost: " << ability.getManaCost() << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    ClassType type;
    std::string name;
    std::map<std::string, int> baseStats;
    std::vector<Ability> abilities;
};

class Character {
public:
    Character(std::string name, const CharacterClass& charClass)
        : name(name), characterClass(charClass) {
        stats = charClass.getBaseStats();
    }

    void levelUp() {
        level++;
        // Increase stats based on class
        for (auto& [stat, value] : stats) {
            value += (characterClass.getType() == ClassType::Warrior && stat == "Strength") ? 2 : 1;
        }
        std::cout << name << " leveled up to " << level << "!" << std::endl;
    }

    void displayCharacterSheet() const {
        std::cout << "=== Character Sheet ===" << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Name: " << name << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Level: " << level << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Class: " << characterClass.getName() << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Stats:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [stat, value] : stats) {
            std::cout << "  " << stat << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    std::string name;
    CharacterClass characterClass;
    int level = 1;
    std::map<std::string, int> stats;
};

int main() {
    // Define classes
    CharacterClass warriorClass(ClassType::Warrior, "Warrior", {{"Strength", 10}, {"Dexterity", 6}, {"Intelligence", 4}});
    warriorClass.addAbility(Ability("Slash", 5, 0));
    warriorClass.addAbility(Ability("Shield Bash", 3, 2));

    CharacterClass mageClass(ClassType::Mage, "Mage", {{"Strength", 3}, {"Dexterity", 6}, {"Intelligence", 10}});
    mageClass.addAbility(Ability("Fireball", 8, 5));
    mageClass.addAbility(Ability("Frost Nova", 6, 4));

    // Create characters
    Character warrior("Conan", warriorClass);
    Character mage("Gandalf", mageClass);

    // Display initial character sheets
    warrior.displayCharacterSheet();
    mage.displayCharacterSheet();

    // Level up characters
    warrior.levelUp();
    mage.levelUp();

    // Display updated character sheets
    warrior.displayCharacterSheet();
    mage.displayCharacterSheet();

    // Display class info
    std::cout << "\nWarrior Class Info:" << std::endl;
    warriorClass.displayInfo();

    std::cout << "\nMage Class Info:" << std::endl;
    mageClass.displayInfo();

    return 0;
}

    This expanded implementation demonstrates:

    1. Distinct classes with different base stats
    2. Class-specific abilities
    3. Stat growth that varies based on class
    4. A basic leveling system that reflects class differences

    You can further expand this system by adding more classes, implementing a more complex ability system (perhaps with cooldowns or resource management), or adding equipment that interacts differently with each class. The key is to create meaningful differences between classes while maintaining overall game balance.

    Attribute Systems

    Let's add an attribute system to our Character class:

    class Character {
public:
    // ... previous code ...

    void setAttributes(int strength, int dexterity, int intelligence) {
        attributes["Strength"] = strength;
        attributes["Dexterity"] = dexterity;
        attributes["Intelligence"] = intelligence;
    }

    void improveAttribute(const std::string& attrName, int amount) {
        if (attributes.find(attrName) != attributes.end()) {
            attributes[attrName] += amount;
            std::cout << name << "'s " << attrName << " increased by " << amount << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Attribute not found!" << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void displayAttributes() const {
        std::cout << "Attributes:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [attr, value] : attributes) {
            std::cout << attr << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    // ... previous code ...
    std::map<std::string, int> attributes;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero", CharacterClass::Warrior);
    hero.setAttributes(10, 8, 6);
    hero.improveAttribute("Strength", 2);
    hero.displayAttributes();
    return 0;
}

    Faction Systems

    Finally, let's implement a basic faction system:

    class Faction {
public:
    Faction(std::string name) : name(name) {}
    std::string getName() const { return name; }

private:
    std::string name;
};

class Character {
public:
    // ... previous code ...

    void joinFaction(const Faction& faction) {
        factions.push_back(faction);
        std::cout << name << " joined the " << faction.getName() << " faction." << std::endl;
    }

    void displayFactions() const {
        std::cout << "Factions:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& faction : factions) {
            std::cout << "- " << faction.getName() << std::endl;
        }
    }

private:
    // ... previous code ...
    std::vector<Faction> factions;
};

// Usage example
int main() {
    Character hero("Hero", CharacterClass::Warrior);
    Faction knights("Knights of the Round Table");
    hero.joinFaction(knights);
    hero.displayFactions();
    return 0;
}

    Now, let's combine all these systems into a comprehensive Character class:

    #include <iostream>
#include <string>
#include <vector>
#include <map>

enum class CharacterClass { Warrior, Mage, Rogue };

class Skill {
public:
    Skill(std::string name, int level = 0) : name(name), level(level) {}

    void levelUp() { ++level; }
    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    int getLevel() const { return level; }

private:
    std::string name;
    int level;
};

class Faction {
public:
    Faction(std::string name) : name(name) {}
    std::string getName() const { return name; }

private:
    std::string name;
};

class Character {
public:
    Character(std::string name, CharacterClass charClass) 
        : name(name), characterClass(charClass), level(1), experience(0) {}

    // Character Creation and Basic Info
    std::string getName() const { return name; }
    int getLevel() const { return level; }

    // Character Customization
    void setAppearance(std::string hairColor, std::string eyeColor, std::string skinTone) {
        appearance["Hair Color"] = hairColor;
        appearance["Eye Color"] = eyeColor;
        appearance["Skin Tone"] = skinTone;
    }

    // Skill System
    void learnSkill(const Skill& skill) {
        skills.push_back(skill);
    }

    void improveSkill(const std::string& skillName) {
        for (auto& skill : skills) {
            if (skill.getName() == skillName) {
                skill.levelUp();
                std::cout << name << " improved " << skillName << " to level " << skill.getLevel() << std::endl;
                return;
            }
        }
        std::cout << "Skill not found!" << std::endl;
    }

    // Leveling System
    void gainExperience(int exp) {
        experience += exp;
        std::cout << name << " gained " << exp << " experience points." << std::endl;
        checkLevelUp();
    }

    // Class System
    void displayClass() const {
        std::cout << "Class: ";
        switch (characterClass) {
            case CharacterClass::Warrior: std::cout << "Warrior"; break;
            case CharacterClass::Mage: std::cout << "Mage"; break;
            case CharacterClass::Rogue: std::cout << "Rogue"; break;
        }
        std::cout << std::endl;
    }

    // Attribute System
    void setAttributes(int strength, int dexterity, int intelligence) {
        attributes["Strength"] = strength;
        attributes["Dexterity"] = dexterity;
        attributes["Intelligence"] = intelligence;
    }

    void improveAttribute(const std::string& attrName, int amount) {
        if (attributes.find(attrName) != attributes.end()) {
            attributes[attrName] += amount;
            std::cout << name << "'s " << attrName << " increased by " << amount << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Attribute not found!" << std::endl;
        }
    }

    // Faction System
    void joinFaction(const Faction& faction) {
        factions.push_back(faction);
        std::cout << name << " joined the " << faction.getName() << " faction." << std::endl;
    }

    // Display Methods
    void displayAppearance() const {
        std::cout << "Appearance:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [feature, value] : appearance) {
            std::cout << feature << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void displaySkills() const {
        std::cout << "Skills:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& skill : skills) {
            std::cout << "- " << skill.getName() << " (Level " << skill.getLevel() << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void displayAttributes() const {
        std::cout << "Attributes:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& [attr, value] : attributes) {
            std::cout << attr << ": " << value << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void displayFactions() const {
        std::cout << "Factions:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& faction : factions) {
            std::cout << "- " << faction.getName() << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void displayCharacterSheet() const {
        std::cout << "=== Character Sheet ===" << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Name: " << name << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Level: " << level << std::endl;
        std::cout << "Experience: " << experience << std::endl;
        displayClass();
        displayAppearance();
        displayAttributes();
        displaySkills();
        displayFactions();
    }

private:
    std::string name;
    CharacterClass characterClass;
    int level;
    int experience;
    std::map<std::string, std::string> appearance;
    std::vector<Skill> skills;
    std::map<std::string, int> attributes;
    std::vector<Faction> factions;

    void checkLevelUp() {
        int expRequired = level * 100; // Simple formula: level * 100 exp to level up
        if (experience >= expRequired) {
            level++;
            experience -= expRequired;
            std::cout << name << " leveled up to level " << level << "!" << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    Character hero("Aleria", CharacterClass::Mage);

    // Character Customization
    hero.setAppearance("Silver", "Green", "Pale");

    // Skill System
    hero.learnSkill(Skill("Fireball"));
    hero.learnSkill(Skill("Teleport"));
    hero.improveSkill("Fireball");

    // Leveling System
    hero.gainExperience(150);

    // Attribute System
    hero.setAttributes(5, 8, 15);
    hero.improveAttribute("Intelligence", 2);

    // Faction System
    Faction mageGuild("Mage's Guild");
    hero.joinFaction(mageGuild);

    // Display Character Sheet
    hero.displayCharacterSheet();

    return 0;
}

    This comprehensive character system includes all the requested features:

    1. Character Creation
    2. Character Customization
    3. Skill Trees and Progression
    4. Leveling Systems
    5. Class Systems
    6. Attribute Systems
    7. Faction Systems

    The main function demonstrates how to use this character system. You can further expand this system by adding more complex interactions between skills, attributes, and classes, implementing equipment systems, or adding more detailed progression mechanics.

    Inventory and Item Systems

    Inventory and item systems are fundamental in many games, providing ways for players to manage items, craft new items, loot, equip gear, and deal with item durability and weight. Below are detailed explanations and implementations in C++ for various inventory and item systems.

    Inventory Management

    Inventory management systems allow players to store and manage items. This includes adding, removing, and organizing items.

    Explanation:

    • An inventory typically consists of a collection of items.
    • Players can add items to the inventory, remove items, and check their current inventory.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;

    Item(const std::string& itemName) : name(itemName) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::vector<Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items.push_back(item);
        std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory." << std::endl;
    }

    void removeItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (auto it = items.begin(); it != items.end(); ++it) {
            if (it->name == itemName) {
                std::cout << itemName << " removed from inventory." << std::endl;
                items.erase(it);
                return;
            }
        }
        std::cout << itemName << " not found in inventory." << std::endl;
    }

    void listItems() {
        std::cout << "Inventory contains:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.name << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory inventory;
    inventory.addItem(Item("Sword"));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Shield"));
    inventory.listItems();
    inventory.removeItem("Sword");
    inventory.listItems();
    return 0;
}

    Crafting Systems

    Crafting systems allow players to combine items to create new ones. This involves defining recipes and managing the crafting process.

    Explanation:

    • Players use recipes to craft new items from existing ones.
    • The system checks if the player has the required items and then removes them to produce the new item.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <unordered_map>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;

    Item(const std::string& itemName) : name(itemName) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::vector<Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items.push_back(item);
        std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory." << std::endl;
    }

    bool removeItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (auto it = items.begin(); it != items.end(); ++it) {
            if (it->name == itemName) {
                items.erase(it);
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }

    bool hasItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            if (item.name == itemName) {
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }
};

class CraftingRecipe {
public:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, int> ingredients;
    Item result;

    CraftingRecipe(const std::unordered_map<std::string, int>& recipeIngredients, const Item& recipeResult)
        : ingredients(recipeIngredients), result(recipeResult) {}
};

class CraftingSystem {
private:
    Inventory& inventory;

public:
    CraftingSystem(Inventory& inv) : inventory(inv) {}

    void craft(const CraftingRecipe& recipe) {
        for (const auto& ingredient : recipe.ingredients) {
            int count = ingredient.second;
            while (count-- > 0) {
                if (!inventory.removeItem(ingredient.first)) {
                    std::cout << "Missing ingredient: " << ingredient.first << std::endl;
                    return;
                }
            }
        }
        inventory.addItem(recipe.result);
        std::cout << "Crafted: " << recipe.result.name << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory inventory;
    inventory.addItem(Item("Wood"));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Wood"));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Stone"));

    CraftingRecipe axeRecipe({{"Wood", 2}, {"Stone", 1}}, Item("Axe"));

    CraftingSystem craftingSystem(inventory);
    craftingSystem.craft(axeRecipe);
    inventory.listItems();
    return 0;
}

    Looting Systems

    Looting systems enable players to collect items from defeated enemies or found containers.

    Explanation:

    • Items are generated based on predefined loot tables or random drops.
    • Players can collect these items and add them to their inventory.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <cstdlib>
#include <ctime>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;

    Item(const std::string& itemName) : name(itemName) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::vector<Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items.push_back(item);
        std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory." << std::endl;
    }

    void listItems() {
        std::cout << "Inventory contains:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.name << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

class LootTable {
private:
    std::vector<Item> possibleLoot;

public:
    void addItemToLootTable(const Item& item) {
        possibleLoot.push_back(item);
    }

    Item getRandomLoot() {
        if (possibleLoot.empty()) {
            return Item("Empty");
        }
        int index = rand() % possibleLoot.size();
        return possibleLoot[index];
    }
};

class LootingSystem {
private:
    Inventory& inventory;
    LootTable& lootTable;

public:
    LootingSystem(Inventory& inv, LootTable& table) : inventory(inv), lootTable(table) {}

    void loot() {
        Item item = lootTable.getRandomLoot();
        inventory.addItem(item);
        std::cout << "Looted: " << item.name << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    srand(time(0));

    Inventory inventory;
    LootTable lootTable;

    lootTable.addItemToLootTable(Item("Gold Coin"));
    lootTable.addItemToLootTable(Item("Silver Coin"));
    lootTable.addItemToLootTable(Item("Health Potion"));

    LootingSystem lootingSystem(inventory, lootTable);
    lootingSystem.loot();
    lootingSystem.loot();
    lootingSystem.loot();

    inventory.listItems();
    return 0;
}

    Equipment Systems

    Equipment systems manage the items that a player can equip, such as weapons, armor, and accessories.

    Explanation:

    • Players can equip and unequip items.
    • Equipped items may provide benefits or abilities.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <unordered_map>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;

    Item(const std::string& itemName) : name(itemName) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::vector<Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items.push_back(item);
        std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory." << std::endl;
    }

    bool removeItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (auto it = items.begin(); it != items.end(); ++it) {
            if (it->name == itemName) {
                items.erase(it);
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }

    bool hasItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            if (item.name == itemName) {
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }

    void listItems() {
        std::cout << "Inventory contains:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.name << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

class EquipmentSystem {
private:
    Inventory& inventory;
    std::unordered_map<std::string, Item> equippedItems;

public:
    EquipmentSystem(Inventory& inv) : inventory(inv) {}

    void equipItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        if (inventory.hasItem(itemName)) {
            equippedItems[itemName] = Item(itemName);
            inventory.removeItem(itemName);
            std::cout << "Equipped " << itemName << "." << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << itemName << " not found in inventory." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void unequipItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        auto it = equippedItems.find(itemName);
        if (it != equippedItems.end()) {
            inventory.addItem(it->second);
            equippedItems.erase(it);
            std::cout << "Unequipped " << itemName << "." << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << itemName << " is not equipped." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void listEquippedItems() {
        std::cout << "Equipped items:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : equippedItems) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.first << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory inventory;
    inventory.addItem

(Item("Sword"));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Shield"));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Helmet"));

    EquipmentSystem equipmentSystem(inventory);
    equipmentSystem.equipItem("Sword");
    equipmentSystem.equipItem("Shield");
    equipmentSystem.listEquippedItems();
    inventory.listItems();

    equipmentSystem.unequipItem("Sword");
    equipmentSystem.listEquippedItems();
    inventory.listItems();

    return 0;
}

    Durability Systems

    Durability systems track the wear and tear of items, requiring maintenance or replacement over time.

    Explanation:

    • Items have a durability value that decreases with use.
    • Items may break when their durability reaches zero.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <unordered_map>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;
    int durability;

    Item(const std::string& itemName, int itemDurability) : name(itemName), durability(itemDurability) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items[item.name] = item;
        std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory with durability " << item.durability << "." << std::endl;
    }

    void useItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        auto it = items.find(itemName);
        if (it != items.end()) {
            it->second.durability--;
            std::cout << it->second.name << " used. Durability: " << it->second.durability << std::endl;
            if (it->second.durability <= 0) {
                std::cout << it->second.name << " broke!" << std::endl;
                items.erase(it);
            }
        } else {
            std::cout << itemName << " not found in inventory." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void listItems() {
        std::cout << "Inventory contains:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.second.name << " (Durability: " << item.second.durability << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory inventory;
    inventory.addItem(Item("Sword", 5));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Shield", 10));

    inventory.useItem("Sword");
    inventory.useItem("Sword");
    inventory.useItem("Sword");
    inventory.useItem("Sword");
    inventory.useItem("Sword");

    inventory.listItems();
    return 0;
}

    Weight Systems

    Weight systems manage the total weight of items in an inventory, affecting the player's ability to carry items.

    Explanation:

    • Each item has a weight.
    • The total weight of the inventory affects the player's carrying capacity.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <unordered_map>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;
    float weight;

    Item(const std::string& itemName, float itemWeight) : name(itemName), weight(itemWeight) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, Item> items;
    float totalWeight = 0.0f;
    const float maxWeight = 50.0f;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        if (totalWeight + item.weight <= maxWeight) {
            items[item.name] = item;
            totalWeight += item.weight;
            std::cout << item.name << " added to inventory. Total weight: " << totalWeight << "/" << maxWeight << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Cannot add " << item.name << ". Exceeds maximum weight." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void removeItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        auto it = items.find(itemName);
        if (it != items.end()) {
            totalWeight -= it->second.weight;
            items.erase(it);
            std::cout << itemName << " removed from inventory. Total weight: " << totalWeight << "/" << maxWeight << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << itemName << " not found in inventory." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void listItems() {
        std::cout << "Inventory contains:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << "- " << item.second.name << " (Weight: " << item.second.weight << ")" << std::endl;
        }
        std::cout << "Total weight: " << totalWeight << "/" << maxWeight << std::endl;
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory inventory;
    inventory.addItem(Item("Sword", 5.0f));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Shield", 10.0f));
    inventory.addItem(Item("Helmet", 3.0f));

    inventory.listItems();
    inventory.removeItem("Shield");
    inventory.listItems();

    return 0;
}

    These implementations cover various aspects of inventory and item systems in games. Each system can be further expanded and customized based on the specific needs and complexity of the game being developed.

    Quest and Narrative Systems

    Quest Tracking

    Quest tracking systems manage the player's progress through various tasks or missions in the game.

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <unordered_map>

enum class QuestStatus { NOT_STARTED, IN_PROGRESS, COMPLETED, FAILED };

class Quest {
private:
    std::string id;
    std::string title;
    std::string description;
    QuestStatus status;
    std::vector<std::string> objectives;
    std::unordered_map<std::string, bool> objectiveCompletion;

public:
    Quest(std::string id, std::string title, std::string description)
        : id(id), title(title), description(description), status(QuestStatus::NOT_STARTED) {}

    void addObjective(const std::string& objective) {
        objectives.push_back(objective);
        objectiveCompletion[objective] = false;
    }

    void startQuest() { status = QuestStatus::IN_PROGRESS; }

    void completeObjective(const std::string& objective) {
        if (objectiveCompletion.find(objective) != objectiveCompletion.end()) {
            objectiveCompletion[objective] = true;
            if (std::all_of(objectiveCompletion.begin(), objectiveCompletion.end(), 
                            [](const auto& pair) { return pair.second; })) {
                status = QuestStatus::COMPLETED;
            }
        }
    }

    QuestStatus getStatus() const { return status; }
    // Other getters and methods...
};

class QuestManager {
private:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, Quest> quests;

public:
    void addQuest(const Quest& quest) {
        quests[quest.getId()] = quest;
    }

    void startQuest(const std::string& questId) {
        if (quests.find(questId) != quests.end()) {
            quests[questId].startQuest();
        }
    }

    void completeObjective(const std::string& questId, const std::string& objective) {
        if (quests.find(questId) != quests.end()) {
            quests[questId].completeObjective(objective);
        }
    }

    // Other methods for quest management...
};

    Dialogue Systems

    Dialogue systems manage conversations between characters, often including player choices.

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <functional>

class DialogueOption {
public:
    std::string text;
    std::function<void()> action;

    DialogueOption(const std::string& t, std::function<void()> a) : text(t), action(a) {}
};

class DialogueNode {
public:
    std::string text;
    std::vector<DialogueOption> options;

    DialogueNode(const std::string& t) : text(t) {}

    void addOption(const std::string& optionText, std::function<void()> action) {
        options.emplace_back(optionText, action);
    }
};

class DialogueSystem {
private:
    std::vector<DialogueNode> dialogue;
    size_t currentNode;

public:
    DialogueSystem() : currentNode(0) {}

    void addNode(const DialogueNode& node) {
        dialogue.push_back(node);
    }

    void displayCurrentNode() {
        if (currentNode < dialogue.size()) {
            std::cout << dialogue[currentNode].text << std::endl;
            for (size_t i = 0; i < dialogue[currentNode].options.size(); ++i) {
                std::cout << i + 1 << ". " << dialogue[currentNode].options[i].text << std::endl;
            }
        }
    }

    void chooseOption(size_t option) {
        if (currentNode < dialogue.size() && option <= dialogue[currentNode].options.size()) {
            dialogue[currentNode].options[option - 1].action();
        }
    }

    // Other methods for managing dialogue flow...
};

    Choice and Consequence Systems

    These systems track player decisions and their impact on the game world.

    #include <iostream>
#include <unordered_map>
#include <string>

class ChoiceAndConsequenceSystem {
private:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, int> playerChoices;
    std::unordered_map<std::string, std::function<void(int)>> consequences;

public:
    void recordChoice(const std::string& choiceId, int value) {
        playerChoices[choiceId] = value;
    }

    void addConsequence(const std::string& choiceId, std::function<void(int)> consequence) {
        consequences[choiceId] = consequence;
    }

    void applyConsequences() {
        for (const auto& choice : playerChoices) {
            if (consequences.find(choice.first) != consequences.end()) {
                consequences[choice.first](choice.second);
            }
        }
    }

    int getChoiceValue(const std::string& choiceId) const {
        auto it = playerChoices.find(choiceId);
        return (it != playerChoices.end()) ? it->second : 0;
    }
};

    Branching Narratives

    Branching narratives allow for multiple story paths based on player choices.

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <memory>

class StoryNode {
public:
    std::string text;
    std::vector<std::unique_ptr<StoryNode>> children;

    StoryNode(const std::string& t) : text(t) {}

    void addChild(std::unique_ptr<StoryNode> child) {
        children.push_back(std::move(child));
    }
};

class BranchingNarrativeSystem {
private:
    std::unique_ptr<StoryNode> root;
    StoryNode* currentNode;

public:
    BranchingNarrativeSystem(std::unique_ptr<StoryNode> rootNode) : root(std::move(rootNode)), currentNode(root.get()) {}

    void displayCurrentNode() {
        if (currentNode) {
            std::cout << currentNode->text << std::endl;
            for (size_t i = 0; i < currentNode->children.size(); ++i) {
                std::cout << i + 1 << ". " << currentNode->children[i]->text << std::endl;
            }
        }
    }

    void chooseOption(size_t option) {
        if (currentNode && option <= currentNode->children.size()) {
            currentNode = currentNode->children[option - 1].get();
        }
    }

    // Other methods for managing the narrative...
};

    Cutscene Systems

    Cutscene systems manage non-interactive story sequences.

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <chrono>
#include <thread>

class CutsceneEvent {
public:
    virtual void execute() = 0;
    virtual ~CutsceneEvent() = default;
};

class DialogueEvent : public CutsceneEvent {
private:
    std::string character;
    std::string line;

public:
    DialogueEvent(const std::string& c, const std::string& l) : character(c), line(l) {}

    void execute() override {
        std::cout << character << ": " << line << std::endl;
        std::this_thread::sleep_for(std::chrono::seconds(2));
    }
};

class CameraEvent : public CutsceneEvent {
private:
    std::string action;

public:
    CameraEvent(const std::string& a) : action(a) {}

    void execute() override {
        std::cout << "Camera: " << action << std::endl;
        std::this_thread::sleep_for(std::chrono::seconds(1));
    }
};

class CutsceneSystem {
private:
    std::vector<std::unique_ptr<CutsceneEvent>> events;

public:
    void addEvent(std::unique_ptr<CutsceneEvent> event) {
        events.push_back(std::move(event));
    }

    void playCutscene() {
        for (const auto& event : events) {
            event->execute();
        }
    }
};

    Journal/Codex Systems

    These systems manage in-game information and lore.

    #include <iostream>
#include <unordered_map>
#include <string>
#include <vector>

class CodexEntry {
public:
    std::string title;
    std::string content;
    bool isUnlocked;

    CodexEntry(const std::string& t, const std::string& c) : title(t), content(c), isUnlocked(false) {}
};

class JournalCodexSystem {
private:
    std::unordered_map<std::string, CodexEntry> codex;
    std::vector<std::string> journal;

public:
    void addCodexEntry(const std::string& id, const CodexEntry& entry) {
        codex[id] = entry;
    }

    void unlockCodexEntry(const std::string& id) {
        auto it = codex.find(id);
        if (it != codex.end()) {
            it->second.isUnlocked = true;
        }
    }

    void addJournalEntry(const std::string& entry) {
        journal.push_back(entry);
    }

    void displayCodex() const {
        for (const auto& entry : codex) {
            if (entry.second.isUnlocked) {
                std::cout << entry.second.title << ": " << entry.second.content << std::endl;
            }
        }
    }

    void displayJournal() const {
        for (const auto& entry : journal) {
            std::cout << entry << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

    These systems work together to create rich, interactive narratives:

    • The Quest Tracking system manages player progress through various tasks.
    • The Dialogue System handles conversations and player choices within them.
    • The Choice and Consequence System tracks important decisions and their effects.
    • The Branching Narrative System manages the overall story structure.
    • The Cutscene System handles non-interactive story sequences.
    • The Journal/Codex System provides additional context and lore.

    In a full game implementation, these systems would be more complex and interconnected. They might use event systems to communicate, serialization for save/load functionality, and integrate with other game systems like character progression or world state management.

    Economy Systems

    Economy systems add depth to games by enabling players to manage currency, trade items, participate in auctions, use banking systems, and buy/sell real estate. Below are explanations and C++ implementations for these systems.

    Currency Systems

    Currency systems manage in-game money that players can earn, spend, and exchange.

    Explanation:

    • Players earn currency through various actions (e.g., completing quests, selling items).
    • Currency can be spent on items, services, and more.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>

class CurrencySystem {
private:
    int balance;

public:
    CurrencySystem() : balance(0) {}

    void addCurrency(int amount) {
        balance += amount;
        std::cout << "Added " << amount << " currency. New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
    }

    void spendCurrency(int amount) {
        if (balance >= amount) {
            balance -= amount;
            std::cout << "Spent " << amount << " currency. New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Insufficient balance." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    int getBalance() const {
        return balance;
    }
};

int main() {
    CurrencySystem currencySystem;
    currencySystem.addCurrency(100);
    currencySystem.spendCurrency(30);
    std::cout << "Final balance: " << currencySystem.getBalance() << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

    Trading Systems

    Trading systems allow players to exchange items and currency with each other or with NPCs.

    Explanation:

    • Players can offer items and/or currency in exchange for other items and/or currency.
    • Trades can be accepted or declined based on set conditions.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>

class Item {
public:
    std::string name;
    int value;

    Item(const std::string& itemName, int itemValue) : name(itemName), value(itemValue) {}
};

class Inventory {
private:
    std::vector<Item> items;

public:
    void addItem(const Item& item) {
        items.push_back(item);
    }

    bool removeItem(const std::string& itemName) {
        for (auto it = items.begin(); it != items.end(); ++it) {
            if (it->name == itemName) {
                items.erase(it);
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }

    bool hasItem(const std::string& itemName) const {
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            if (item.name == itemName) {
                return true;
            }
        }
        return false;
    }

    void listItems() const {
        for (const auto& item : items) {
            std::cout << item.name << " (Value: " << item.value << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

class TradingSystem {
private:
    Inventory& playerInventory;
    Inventory& npcInventory;

public:
    TradingSystem(Inventory& playerInv, Inventory& npcInv) : playerInventory(playerInv), npcInventory(npcInv) {}

    void trade(const std::string& playerItem, const std::string& npcItem) {
        if (playerInventory.hasItem(playerItem) && npcInventory.hasItem(npcItem)) {
            playerInventory.removeItem(playerItem);
            npcInventory.removeItem(npcItem);
            playerInventory.addItem(Item(npcItem, 0)); // Assuming item values are irrelevant for now
            npcInventory.addItem(Item(playerItem, 0));
            std::cout << "Traded " << playerItem << " for " << npcItem << "." << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Trade failed. One or both items not found." << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    Inventory playerInventory;
    Inventory npcInventory;

    playerInventory.addItem(Item("Sword", 100));
    npcInventory.addItem(Item("Shield", 150));

    TradingSystem tradingSystem(playerInventory, npcInventory);
    tradingSystem.trade("Sword", "Shield");

    std::cout << "Player Inventory:" << std::endl;
    playerInventory.listItems();

    std::cout << "NPC Inventory:" << std::endl;
    npcInventory.listItems();

    return 0;
}

    Auction Houses

    Auction houses allow players to bid on items offered by other players within a specific timeframe.

    Explanation:

    • Items are listed for auction with a starting price.
    • Players can place bids higher than the current highest bid.
    • The highest bid at the end of the auction wins the item.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>
#include <algorithm>

class Bid {
public:
    std::string bidder;
    int amount;

    Bid(const std::string& bidderName, int bidAmount) : bidder(bidderName), amount(bidAmount) {}
};

class AuctionItem {
public:
    std::string name;
    int startingPrice;
    std::vector<Bid> bids;

    AuctionItem(const std::string& itemName, int startPrice) : name(itemName), startingPrice(startPrice) {}

    void placeBid(const std::string& bidder, int amount) {
        bids.push_back(Bid(bidder, amount));
        std::sort(bids.begin(), bids.end(), [](const Bid& a, const Bid& b) { return a.amount > b.amount; });
        std::cout << bidder << " placed a bid of " << amount << " on " << name << "." << std::endl;
    }

    void endAuction() {
        if (!bids.empty()) {
            std::cout << "Auction ended. " << name << " sold to " << bids[0].bidder << " for " << bids[0].amount << "." << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Auction ended. No bids placed on " << name << "." << std::endl;
        }
    }
};

int main() {
    AuctionItem sword("Sword of Destiny", 100);
    sword.placeBid("Player1", 150);
    sword.placeBid("Player2", 200);
    sword.placeBid("Player1", 250);
    sword.endAuction();

    return 0;
}

    Banking Systems

    Banking systems allow players to deposit and withdraw currency, often providing interest over time.

    Explanation:

    • Players can store their currency in a bank to keep it safe or earn interest.
    • Deposits and withdrawals are managed by the bank.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>

class Bank {
private:
    int balance;
    const float interestRate;

public:
    Bank(float rate) : balance(0), interestRate(rate) {}

    void deposit(int amount) {
        balance += amount;
        std::cout << "Deposited " << amount << " currency. New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
    }

    void withdraw(int amount) {
        if (balance >= amount) {
            balance -= amount;
            std::cout << "Withdrew " << amount << " currency. New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Insufficient balance." << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void applyInterest() {
        int interest = balance * interestRate;
        balance += interest;
        std::cout << "Applied interest. New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
    }

    int getBalance() const {
        return balance;
    }
};

int main() {
    Bank bank(0.05); // 5% interest rate
    bank.deposit(1000);
    bank.applyInterest();
    bank.withdraw(300);
    bank.applyInterest();
    std::cout << "Final balance: " << bank.getBalance() << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

    Real Estate/Property Systems

    Real estate systems enable players to buy, sell, and manage properties, which can generate income or provide other benefits.

    Explanation:

    • Players can purchase properties that may generate rental income or provide strategic advantages.
    • Properties can be sold or upgraded.

    Implementation in C++:

    #include <iostream>
#include <vector>
#include <string>

class Property {
public:
    std::string name;
    int value;
    int rentalIncome;

    Property(const std::string& propertyName, int propertyValue, int rental) 
        : name(propertyName), value(propertyValue), rentalIncome(rental) {}
};

class RealEstateSystem {
private:
    std::vector<Property> properties;
    int balance;

public:
    RealEstateSystem() : balance(0) {}

    void buyProperty(const Property& property) {
        if (balance >= property.value) {
            properties.push_back(property);
            balance -= property.value;
            std::cout << "Bought property: " << property.name << std::endl;
        } else {
            std::cout << "Insufficient funds to buy " << property.name << std::endl;
        }
    }

    void sellProperty(const std::string& propertyName) {
        for (auto it = properties.begin(); it != properties.end(); ++it) {
            if (it->name == propertyName) {
                balance += it->value;
                std::cout << "Sold property: " << it->name << std::endl;
                properties.erase(it);
                return;
            }
        }
        std::cout << "Property not found: " << propertyName << std::endl;
    }

    void collectRent() {
        int totalRent = 0;
        for (const auto& property : properties

) {
            totalRent += property.rentalIncome;
        }
        balance += totalRent;
        std::cout << "Collected rent: " << totalRent << ". New balance: " << balance << std::endl;
    }

    void listProperties() const {
        std::cout << "Properties owned:" << std::endl;
        for (const auto& property : properties) {
            std::cout << "- " << property.name << " (Value: " << property.value << ", Rent: " << property.rentalIncome << ")" << std::endl;
        }
    }

    int getBalance() const {
        return balance;
    }
};

int main() {
    RealEstateSystem realEstateSystem;
    realEstateSystem.buyProperty(Property("House", 500, 50));
    realEstateSystem.buyProperty(Property("Apartment", 1000, 100));

    realEstateSystem.collectRent();
    realEstateSystem.sellProperty("House");

    realEstateSystem.listProperties();
    std::cout << "Final balance: " << realEstateSystem.getBalance() << std::endl;
    return 0;
}

    These examples illustrate basic implementations of various economy systems. Each system can be expanded with more features, better error handling, and integration with other game systems to enhance the gameplay experience.
